awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: IIBR Instrumentation: The Nanosizer - A new tool for the preparation of arbitrary bioactive surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Northwestern University and the City University of New York to develop an instrument capable of synthesizing arbitrary 3D nanopatterns of biologically active materials, coined “the Nanosizer.” The development of said instrument, the instrument itself, and the new photochemistry developed, will have wide reaching impacts on trainees, the nearby Chicago and New York City communities, and the broader scientific community. Both Mirkin and Braunschweig groups have previously and will continue to mentor trainees, including undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, on the design of experiments and communication skills. Importantly, the researchers will lead the experimentation effort and work closely with the PIs on the dissemination of results through high-impact publications, patents, grant reports, and conference presentations. Exposure to all aspects of the research process will provide trainees with the highest probability of success on their paths forward, as proven by the track record of academic and industrial job placement from the two groups. The neighboring Chicago and New York communities stand to benefit from the award, through participation in outreach endeavors. Braunschweig group will participate in the Research Internships in Materials Science and Mirkin members will volunteer with Science In your Community Center with the goal of engaging K-12 students, primarily those from traditionally underrepresented groups, in science and technology.
 
The Nanosizer will make arbitrary 3D nanopatterns of biologically active macromolecules with 100 nm resolution a reality through in situ surface patterning and fully orthogonal biomacromolecule construction. Through a combination of beam-pen lithography with 100 nm pixel resolution, precise multiwavelength irradiation control, and continuous flow of variable reagent streams, the Nanosizer will enable control over the reaction conditions at any 100 nm pixel over a >1 cm2 area. This, in conjunction with the development of orthogonal photochemistries for surface functionalization and synthesis of biomolecules, such as oligopeptides, oligonucleotides, and glycans, will enable the massively parallel generation of biomolecule arrays, with each pixel containing a chemically unique and well-defined molecule. Synthetic interfaces coated with biologically active materials have screening and functional applications in nearly every field of biology. The Nanosizer will provide monumental improvements in batch-to-batch reproducibility, resolution size, feature density, feature quantity, and overall cost in the preparation of such substrates. Results from these studies will be published in peer-reviewed journals, presented at scientific meetings, broadly distributed through commercialization, and incorporated into outreach presentations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to (1) develop a new instrument, and (2) establish associated methods for preparing surfaces patterned with delicate, biologically-active materials. This instrument will be the first printing platform capable of being used to prepare truly arbitrary nanopatterns, patterns composed of pixels of immobilized bioactive molecules, with diameters < 100 nm. Further, the instrument will permit the independent control of the chemical composition and height at each pixel (multiplexing) across large (> 1 cm2) substrates. The patterned bioactive materials will include biologically derived molecules, small molecules, and synthetic brush polymers. Taken together, this printing method is referred to as 'Hypersurface Photolithography'. Over the course of this project major advances were made in both areas. A Hypersurface Photolithography system was achieved by combining massively parallel tip arrays, advanced optics, integrated microfluidics, and localized surface chemistry; taken together, a platform for performing iterative chemical synthesis in nanoscale volumes and in a multiplexed fashion was developed. In particular, the advanced optics direct the light from a digital micromirror device (DMD) onto the back of a tip array with spatiotemporal control so that the light focused to each nanoscopic tip can be repeatedly turned on/off. The tip array acts as a waveguide that collimates the light to the nanoscale areas on the surface or locally increases in temperature in response to photoirradiation. Photochemical reactions are induced between functional groups on the surface and reactive molecules in a solution (“inks”) exclusively below the irradiated tips. The microfluidics are coordinated with the DMD to control the composition of the ink new inks into a reactive chamber below the tip arrays. The ability to coordinate the microfluidics and the DMD will result in control of the chemical composition at each pixel or along a growing chain. In addition to the instrument, a new class of living photopolymerizations – the thiol-induced radical photopolymerzations – were invented, which are ideal for using in the Hypersurface Photolithography platform because the height of the resulting polymer brushes can be controlled with irradiation time, and because the reaction can be used to immobilize a wide-range of functionalities onto surfaces. As a demonstration of the benefits of this platform, we have created ultrasensitive glycan microarrays that are capable of detecting glycan-binding proteins at attomolar concentrations, 6-dimensional hypersurfaces, and a method of creating transparent and conductive gold patterns that can be used for next generation optical displays, sensors, and solar cells.
